page.title: 09How people have changed.
page.content: In bygone days, most people ended their education at school leaving age. Men usually worked on the farm while women worked in the farmhouse or in seasonal fieldwork. Today farms are more mechanised and so little work is available. Farmers often dispose of their tied cottages when they become available and other houses have become vacant through old people dying and others moving on.This has led to an influx of new residents. Tetchill's population includes 2 factory managers and several houses have changed hands quite frequently. Most people now work outside the area e.g. at Ellesmere College or at the MMB dairy. Families are smaller than they used to be (2 or 3 is the norm) and most children go on beyond S.L.A. in search of better qualifications. This results in them leaving the village in most cases.
